PC Gamer magazine, the publication, they got their CPUs performance to within a sliver of the 3300X's, Stock performance that is, just using the included Wraith stock cooler. (grunts) - They took our compatibility (laughs). Microsoft and Intel are working together to classify and attack malware by rendering it as an image. Gobbly Gook (claps), because you can't hit what you can't see, okay? The collaboration is called, STAtic Malware-as-Image Network Analysis, or STAMINA, and it involves converting binary file code into pixels, which are then used to compose an image, which is then scanned by a neuro-network for traces of malware infection, which is then reported to your wife, because you've been a bad boy. - [Man] Oh, oh - You can get it from a toilet sit. If that sounds wacky, you are right, it is, but sometimes wacky works because STAMINA has demonstrated over 99% accuracy in classifying malware with a false positive rate of just 2.6%, although it does better with smaller files than larger ones. It really gives a new meaning to the power of visualization, just imagine what a virus looks like, and then you can defeat it. Try it with me now. (lighthearted music) Urgh. - [Man] Urgh. - Gross. - And the vulnerability has been discovered in Thunderbolt, that could allow evil maids, maids? - [Man] Yep. - To hack your PC in five minutes, (claps). Let me explain, the flaw has been named Thunderspy by the researchers that discovered it, because hackers could use it to rewrite your PC's Thunderbolt firmware, and steal your data even if it has an encrypted hard drive. A hypothetical evil maid attack, could involve someone gaining access to your laptop in your hotel room, removing the back plate, using a pre-made device to inject new firmware, and closing your laptop back up, with you being none the wiser. And then that maid just goes and gets a better job, because clearly they are very adapt at IT. - [Man] Oh, man. - No offense to maids, huh.
